EPISTULAE AD BRUTUM, xxw.

For of all the civil wars in our state which I can recall, none were waged on such terms but that whichever side won, at all events some form of free state would have survived. In the present war I should not find it easy to lay down what manner of free state we shall have, if we are to be the winners 3 if we lose, the free state will certainly disappear for ever. Ι therefore advocated severe measures against Antony and against Lepidus, not so much for retribution’s sake, as to diseourage and deter evil—minded citizens from attacking their country at the present time, and to set up a warning example for the future, so that none should feel inclined to repeat such acts of madness.

And yet this particular measure did not reflect ll mine any more than the universal opinion. You see vindictiveness in this, that the penalty extends to the innocent children. But that is an ancient usage and common to all states, if it be true that even Thermistocles’ children were left destitute3 and if the same punishment falls upon citizens condemned by a court, how could we be more lenient towards public enemies ? And what complaint can any man make about me, if he cannot help confessing that if victory had been his he would have treated me more harshly? You have the reasoned statement of my ’ views on this particular subject of honour and> punishment 3 Ι believe you have heard my opinions and pronouncements on other matters.
